title: 1951 Big Ten Conference football season
text:
The 1951 Big Ten Conference football season was the 56th season of <a href="college%20football">college football</a> played by the member schools of the <a href="Big%20Ten%20Conference">Big Ten Conference</a> (also known as the Western Conference and the Big Nine Conference) and was a part of the <a href="1951%20college%20football%20season">1951 college football season</a>.
The <a href="1951%20Illinois%20Fighting%20Illini%20football%20team">1951 Illinois Fighting Illini football team</a>, under head coach <a href="Ray%20Eliot">Ray Eliot</a>, compiled a 9–0–1 record, won the Big Ten championship, was ranked No. 4 in the final AP poll, and defeated <a href="1951%20Stanford%20Indians%20football%20team">Stanford</a> 40–7 in the <a href="1952%20Rose%20Bowl">1952 Rose Bowl</a>. The lone setback was a scoreless tie with <a href="1951%20Ohio%20State%20Buckeyes%20football%20team">Ohio State</a>. Halfback <a href="Johnny%20Karras">Johnny Karras</a> was the Big Ten's only consensus first-team All-American. Linebacker <a href="Chuck%20Boerio">Chuck Boerio</a> was selected as the team's most valuable player.
The <a href="1951%20Wisconsin%20Badgers%20football%20team">1951 Wisconsin Badgers football team</a>, under head coach <a href="Ivy%20Williamson">Ivy Williamson</a>, compiled a 7–1–1 record, led the conference in scoring defense (5.9 points allowed per game), and was ranked No. 8 in the final AP poll. Quarterback <a href="John%20Coatta">John Coatta</a> was the first-team All-Big Ten quarterback. Defensive end <a href="Pat%20O%27Donahue">Pat O'Donahue</a> was selected as a first-team All-American by multiple selectors.
